text: Not too worried about it (for now). I saw a thread where someone was testing it and it wasn’t giving them the same crazy results they saw elsewhere. And then they realized they needed to tweak their inputs quite a bit. I’m not an expert in AI or machine learning, but generally the quality of the outputs will always be dependent on the inputs. As mentioned in your linked tweet, there’s still a human element that’s required for quality work.

text:
Does anyone have experience working on content for companies in healthcare and know what the best practices for including a "Medically reviewed by" section are?

For example, Healthline have a small section with a link to their medical team page where they include a short bio about that person.

elements.text:
Does anyone have experience working on content for companies in healthcare and know what the best practices for including a "Medically reviewed by" section are?

For example, Healthline have a small section with a link to their medical team page where they include a short bio about that person.

text: Unsure of best practices, but I would do something very similar if I were in healthcare these days - especially for private practice. The practice I previously worked for had a web agency who sold a 'library' of content that wasn't very good or helpful, and it wasn't tied to the providers at all. Depending on the org, the only hesitance I could forsee is legal may require extra disclaimers to ensure content isn't taken as medical advice

text:
Hi all! Has anyone here had experience producing roundup articles? Looking for ways to improve the writing process and reader experience. 

How do you vet the submissions? Is there a recommended cap for number of expert opinions? Any advice is appreciated!

elements.text:
Hi all! Has anyone here had experience producing roundup articles? Looking for ways to improve the writing process and reader experience. 

How do you vet the submissions? Is there a recommended cap for number of expert opinions? Any advice is appreciated!

text: What are you thoughts on content promotion in B2B during the summer time (July/August). Do you continue to promote it as usual, or are you waiting until the September so you’re able to reach more people? Do you only wait with promoting your best pieces until September? :thinking_face:

elements.text: What are you thoughts on content promotion in B2B during the summer time (July/August). Do you continue to promote it as usual, or are you waiting until the September so you’re able to reach more people? Do you only wait with promoting your best pieces until September?

text:
i've written roundup articles for myself and for clients. are you the one pitching to people or are you being pitched?

There's no recommended cap but just know your target word count and estimate how many responses will get you there.

When soliciting quotes from experts make it a one- or two-question survey. That will make it easy for them to respond and easy for readers to understand. If you want to introduce some variety you can give different experts different questions.

If you're pitching to people, you should have a contact list that is at least twice as large as the number of people you will actually publish, because not everybody will respond to you, and not all of those who do respond will have useful responses.

Keep in mind that those experts are under NO OBLIGATION to answer your questions. unless you're writing for Forbes they will have no idea who you are and experts may not consider your site/pitch worth responding to. Don't take it personally.

They get pitched 100x a day and yours is just one more in the pile. Show some effort and make your query memorable and unique. Personalize each query to show you value them as individuals

If you're pitching to people, you should have a contact list that is at least twice as large as the number of people you will actually publish, because not everybody will respond to you, and not all of those who do respond will have useful responses.

text: It depends. I would not recommend doing any big brand moves in the summer, but for whatever reason executives love doing this. They can’t possibly wait. I think continuing to publish helpful content that actually solves your audience’s problems through the summer is totally worth doing. It’s also a great time to test new topics to see how they might perform at a time when people are paying more attention.

elements.text: It depends. I would not recommend doing any big brand moves in the summer, but for whatever reason executives love doing this. They can’t possibly wait. I think continuing to publish helpful content that actually solves your audience’s problems through the summer is totally worth doing. It’s also a great time to test new topics to see how they might perform at a time when people are paying more attention.

elements.text: Oops, sorry for not mentioning earlier – we’re the one pitching. Thanks for the great insights,

text:
When you say improve the writing process, do you mean make it easier for yourself or improve the quality of writing in the responses? To make it easier on yourself I'd set up a typeform for respondents to fill out that emulates the format of your post. 

As for the quality of submissions, I go through them all and if it's just a typo here and there I'll fix it. Time permitting I might reach out and ask the person to clarify their response. Otherwise, I'll pass on it. 

And I agree with Patrick, if you pitch about 20 people, prepare to write something with 10 responses.

elements.text:
When you say improve the writing process, do you mean make it easier for yourself or improve the quality of writing in the responses? To make it easier on yourself I'd set up a typeform for respondents to fill out that emulates the format of your post. 

As for the quality of submissions, I go through them all and if it's just a typo here and there I'll fix it. Time permitting I might reach out and ask the person to clarify their response. Otherwise, I'll pass on it. 

And I agree with Patrick, if you pitch about 20 people, prepare to write something with 10 responses.

text:
<@UV5TB6FQW> Both actually – streamlined process and better quality! :)

Thanks for the help – just curious, do you use all submissions or have any guidelines as to who makes it to the published article?

elements.text:
Both actually – streamlined process and better quality! :)

Thanks for the help – just curious, do you use all submissions or have any guidelines as to who makes it to the published article?

text:
well, i pre-vet my list in the first place. If i reach out to them, i want to use their answers. so I use all responses?

The only time i do not use an answer if its too short and too abrupt. Like, "yes, SEO is a good idea." Not helpful. Rate responses based on whether they're actually helpful to your reader. Long responses are great because you have the freedom to edit it down to something that makes the expert sound better.

text: If it's cold outreach, like over HARO, I mention in my outreach that I'm looking for responses to this, and if I end up using their response I'll be sure to mention them/share the link when it's live. So it's not assumed that they'll be included. I think that's fair... If 50 people reply you might end up with a 5K word article :sweat_smile:

text: We also try to be extremely specific with our questions or prompts, and provide 2-3 for respondents to use along with a length request of X-Y sentences. This really helps the writing process because it keeps the article focused and cohesive, but also ensures we have somewhat different takes and topics within the finished product.

text: If it’s sponsored, I would ask the channel for their historical performance numbers over the summer. Do they see any changes during that season? Are there other seasonalities to be aware of? I don’t really see any of those other channels as B2B specifically, so I don’t see why you couldn’t.

text: It’s not sponsored, all organic. I typically see less engagement over the summer time, and have historically waiting with promoting any big pieces until after the summer. Now, the pandemic only adds to the inactivity I’m seeing.

text: I previously created content for a B2B healthcare service (on-site employer health clinics). We never used the "reviewed by" section, but every article that had substantive health information was reviewed by one of our medical directors. Know that's not super helpful, but happy to chat in DM or here if you have other questions!

elements.text: I previously created content for a B2B healthcare service (on-site employer health clinics). We never used the "reviewed by" section, but every article that had substantive health information was reviewed by one of our medical directors. Know that's not super helpful, but happy to chat in DM or here if you have other questions!

text: Hi there! SEO-based content strategist here. I've worked with two medically-related clients and encouraged both to hire a medical expert to review as many articles as possible so that we could mark them as officially reviewed/mitigate any potential SEO penalties. You can do it like Healthline or underneath the article as you might for an "author bio". Ensure that you include their credentials/relevant links and you should be golden! An additional page for all reviewers is useful but not necessarily required in my experience.

elements.text: Hi there! SEO-based content strategist here. I've worked with two medically-related clients and encouraged both to hire a medical expert to review as many articles as possible so that we could mark them as officially reviewed/mitigate any potential SEO penalties. You can do it like Healthline or underneath the article as you might for an "author bio". Ensure that you include their credentials/relevant links and you should be golden! An additional page for all reviewers is useful but not necessarily required in my experience.

text:
oof. i know this struggle. my suggestion is to point back to their goals and say things like, "this is a cool idea, but i'm not sure it'll help you achieve your goals of x,y,z. here's why."

in my experience, clients don't mind friendly pushback. some even prefer it. they hired you to be the expert. prove you are the expert and not just another yes man

text: If they haven't established an editorial mission, back-tracking and developing that might also help get everyone on the same page. We used to get random ideas and articles often, and it felt much easier to say, "Hey, this is the goal and purpose of our blog, which we all agreed on. This article is out of scope of that."

text:
Hey, <@UPM5604VC> I've developed a workbook I use to focus my clients. At the end of the workbook, there's a framework for scoring content based on how well it addresses 1. business goals and 2. user needs. I teach them not to only pursue their highest scoring ideas. Or, if they're really stuck on a low-scoring idea, to adapt it in such a way that it scores better. (For instance, a postpartum coaching organization wanted to share a new mom's journal in a blog series. That scored low. When I pushed them to think about it harder, we came up with the idea of having one of the new moms who had participated in THEIR postpartum coaching group write the journal. That scored higher.) Here's the link to download it. It's not perfect, but I haven't gotten around to writing 2.0 yet.

It sounds like you may have to work through the workbook with them. Many clients. have a hard time defining what their users really need and being very specific about their business goals.

 <https://languagearts.xyz/content-strategy-workbook>

attachments.title: Create a Content Strategy Workbook — Language Arts
attachments.text: If you don’t have a content strategy, you need one. A content strategy forces you to focus. It tells you what to do and — perhaps more importantly — what not to do.
attachments.fallback: Language Arts: Create a Content Strategy Workbook — Language Arts

I teach them not to only pursue their highest scoring ideas. Or, if they're really stuck on a low-scoring idea, to adapt it in such a way that it scores better. (For instance, a postpartum coaching organization wanted to share a new mom's journal in a blog series. That scored low. When I pushed them to think about it harder, we came up with the idea of having one of the new moms who had participated in THEIR postpartum coaching group write the journal. That scored higher.) Here's the link to download it. It's not perfect, but I haven't gotten around to writing 2.0 yet.

It sounds like you may have to work through the workbook with them. Many clients. have a hard time defining what their users really need and being very specific about their business goals.

text: I’ve been in this situation before :stuck_out_tongue: If they’re dragging their feet, I would come up with a quote based on your current insight into the project. Over-quote (put more service items than you think they’ll need) since it’s easier to remove things and decreases risk of doing more than what you’ve agreed on. If you have zero insight into what they want, I would just send a general price list of your services and say you can give a more accurate quote if they give a more defined scope of work. It’s not the _best_ sales approach, but they’ll at least have a frame of reference and hopefully it’ll make it easier for them to give you proper feedback.

sales approach, but they’ll at least have a frame of reference and hopefully it’ll make it easier for them to give you proper feedback.

text:
*Here's what's in there currently:*

• 4 Core Workshops
• Simplifying SEO
• High-Gear Keywords
• SEO Writing Secrets
• Link-Building for Normal People
• Bonus: Pillar Content Masterclass
• Bonus: Access to our private SEO community
• Bonus: Weekly Office Hours
• Bonus: Expert Interviews
• Bonus: Content Idea Generator (100+ ideas!)
• Bonus: Local SEO Masterclass

*Here's what we have coming up in the community:*

1: Content Strategy on Easy Mode

Finally, stop worrying and start creating content knowing you aren't wasting your time.  All you need is the right plan. In SEO for the Rest of Us, we'll put that together.

2: Effective Link Building in 2020 (Without Begging for Backlinks)

I'll share with your five strategies that have helped me and my clients build hundreds of links without ever sending an outreach email.

These in include:
• The Double Data Strategy
• The Authority on Autopilot Strategy
• The Glossary Strategy
• The Pre-Buyer Strategy
• The BTTF Strategy
3: How I Sell SEO and Get Buy-In From Clients

I'll break down exactly how I sell SEO services (without actually 'selling' SEO) and then once I start working with a client, hos I create such strong buy-in for our work that we almost never run into issues getting things implemented.

4: SEO Roadmap

Whew! Finally. The SEO Roadmap will guide your through multiple "phases" taking you from 0 site visitors per month to 500k+ every single month.

You don't need another 500 videos to watch. You just need to know the next step. The SEO Roadmap gets you there.

text:
Hi, everyone. I'm introducing a new service: content sprints. The idea is that clients who want a little of this and a little that hire me to augment their staff with a content expert for 5 days. I'm going to add 30 days of post-engagement Slack support, but need to provide guardrails. That won't include, for instances, me editing a blogpost via Slack.

Have any of you. ever tried anything like this with follow-up support? Do you have any suggestions re; rules or guidelines for the Slack support? (I don't think this is appropriate, but I could—for example—say they can only ask me yes-or-no questions.) I imagine they'll ask me to refresh their memory about a rule, ask if they're using a framework I've introduced correctly, that sort of thing. But I have to impose limits. Would love ideas if you have them or advice if you've tried this.

elements.text:

text: Be very specific about pricing, And time box it. Former employers tend to think they still "own" you and have less of a sense of urgency. Make them name a single POC (this is really important for approvals and payments) and charge them 50% upfront so they have some skin in the game.

attachments.title: 1-on-1 Coaching - Yes and Yes
attachments.text: Imagine: your life and work feel easy + uncomplicated. You have a step-by-step plan that will get you where you want to go.  No more self-sabotage. No more elaborate strategies that overwhelm you. Things in your business and life are … okay, but it all feels so hard. Every dollar feels hard-won, every accomplishment seems... Read more »
attachments.fallback: Yes and Yes: 1-on-1 Coaching - Yes and Yes

elements.text: I haven’t done this personally but have a friend who does coaching/consulting and has always offered some form of followup. Here’s an example from her website—it might be helpful in that it doesn’t give a strict yes/no list, but sets it up in the form of questions clients may have after you wrap up the 5-day session.
What does the week of email support include?

Every coaching client gets seven days of email support after our live session.

Do you have a follow up question about your post-session packet? Did you take my advice about getting new clients and now you have a new client and you’re not sure what to do? Did our work shake loose some new ideas you want feedback on?

Great! My inbox is open to you for a week.

Most of my post-session support comes in the form of Loom video replies; it’s faster and soooo much more personal!
(from
yesandyes.org’s 1-on-1 coaching page

text: Whole Whale and Yoast were insightful for me.

elements.text: Whole Whale and Yoast were insightful for me.

text: I imagine that most of us struggle with content overload and the hundreds of services that are supposed to help manage it. Personally, I think there are as many valid ways to organize content & workflows as there are people. But I’m curious: what’s the *one tool* in your arsenal that’s made the biggest difference to your organization and workflow?

elements.text: I imagine that most of us struggle with content overload and the hundreds of services that are supposed to help manage it. Personally, I think there are as many valid ways to organize content & workflows as there are people. But I’m curious: what’s the
one tool
in your arsenal that’s made the biggest difference to your organization and workflow?

text: Thank you, <@U016162GGD6>! I've never heard of Whole Whale. I'll check it out.

elements.text: Thank you,
! I've never heard of Whole Whale. I'll check it out.

text: BTW, this article prompted the question (my company, Workona, is mentioned in it). Ultimately the author is dissatisfied with all the options out there and opts for a good old fashioned Moleskine :smile: <https://venturebeat.com/2020/07/19/the-content-unbundling-problem-thats-stifling-us/>

attachments.title: The content unbundling problem that’s stifling us
attachments.text: Content is at the peak of unbundled, and there doesn't seem to be any solution in sight. Why can’t there be a platform that everyone likes?
attachments.fallback: VentureBeat: The content unbundling problem that’s stifling us

text: Smartsheet. :raised_hands: We use it for our master content calendar as well as to plan and organize campaigns, video timelines, social dates/milestones, etc across the marketing and creative team.

elements.text: Smartsheet.
We use it for our master content calendar as well as to plan and organize campaigns, video timelines, social dates/milestones, etc across the marketing and creative team.

text: ClickUp :100: It has been a dream for client workflows (and a million other things). I'll start using it for my own content shortly.

elements.text: ClickUp
It has been a dream for client workflows (and a million other things). I'll start using it for my own content shortly.

text: What do you love about ClickUp <@U015HDJ8V9A>? I tried it briefly and got overwhelmed :joy:

elements.text: What do you love about ClickUp
? I tried it briefly and got overwhelmed

text: <@UJFELMVU1> It's a lot to take in at first :joy: But it's super flexible. It's great if you're like me and don't want to bounce between 30 different tools daily. As far as all-in-one tools go, it's the most complete and reasonably-priced one I know of. Plus, the team is very transparent and quick about adding new features so it's getting better all the time.

elements.text: It's a lot to take in at first

But it's super flexible. It's great if you're like me and don't want to bounce between 30 different tools daily. As far as all-in-one tools go, it's the most complete and reasonably-priced one I know of. Plus, the team is very transparent and quick about adding new features so it's getting better all the time.

text: Nice! I’m not an all-in-one tool kind of person, but maybe that’s because I haven’t found the right one yet. I can see how handy ClickUp would be for handling client work

text: I use Taskworld, primarily because I worked there for 5 years and it has now become a habit. It’s a good, solid tool and I think its Kanban experience is one of the best in the market. But it is more expensive than other players like Smartsheet, Clickup, Trello, etc.

elements.text: I use Taskworld, primarily because I worked there for 5 years and it has now become a habit. It’s a good, solid tool and I think its Kanban experience is one of the best in the market. But it is more expensive than other players like Smartsheet, Clickup, Trello, etc.
